However, and although I prosecute gun crimes frequently, there is no red colored hotline phone to the NRA headquarters that I must dial for permission before beginning an investigation or prosecution of any crime involving firearms. I do, however, strongly approve of the role the NRA played in helping pass legislation in 1995 that greatly strengthened the penalties for firearm related violent crimes. I would encourage Mr. Bloomberg to explore the possibility of working with the NRA to enact similar laws that target violent crime in his jurisdiction. The NRA has strongly supported the efforts of Virginia's law enforcement community to fight violent crime over the years, and I have no doubt that the organization can provide the same assistance in New York. 
 
 In Virginia, every buyer from a FFL dealer must complete the transaction forms and pass the background check. There are no exceptions, and federal law requires the dealers to keep these forms for annual inspection. 
 In addition to the federal law regarding background checks, Virginia has a separate background check and straw purchase prohibition statute has been around for quite some time, and over the years it has been revised as new issues arise. The full text of the current code section can be found here:
 
 LIS < Code of Virginia < 18.2-308.2:2 
 
 The 2007 amendment added the following language to the code section:
 
  L1. Any person who attempts to solicit, persuade, encourage, or entice any dealer to transfer or otherwise convey a firearm other than to the actual buyer, as well as any other person who willfully and intentionally aids or abets such person, shall be guilty of a Class 6 felony. This subsection shall not apply to a federal law-enforcement officer or a law-enforcement officer as defined in § 9.1-101, in the performance of his official duties, or other person under his direct supervision.
 And:
 
 "Actual buyer" means a person who executes the consent form required in subsection B or C, or other such firearm transaction records as may be required by federal law.
 
 Before the statute was amended an otherwise qualified buyer's crime consisted of actually obtaining the firearm with the intent to provide it to another who is prohibited. The 2007 change in Virginia's law was intended to prohibit any attempt by any person (other than legitimate controlled law enforcement investigations) to conspire with gun dealers to knowingly violate the background check requirements. This, in fact, is what Bloomberg hired people to try and do in Virginia. 
 
 The amendment was strongly supported by the Attorney General of the time and now Governor Robert McDonnell, a Republican. The law was passed, however, with broad bipartisan support, and was signed into law by Governor Tim Kaine, a Democrat, whom some of you may have heard of from his service as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, his reported strong friendship with the President and his time spent in the media spotlight as a short list candidate for vice president. The change in the law is the result of a great deal of bi-partisan anger in Virginia at Mayor Bloomberg for his activities and his complete unwillingness to notify, work with, or even share information after the fact with local law enforcement. The NRA's influence was not needed to effect his change in the law. I am personally aware that the law enforcement community strongly lobbied for it as a reaction to Bloomberg's activities.
